titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

did.repository: University of Delaware Special Collections Department Morris Library, 181 South College Avenue Newark, DE 19717-5267

bioghist.p: Horacio D. Lewis was born in Panama. He was educated at Colegio Abel Bravo, The University of Panama, The Canal Zone College, Morningside College, Northeastern Illinois University, Harvard University, Columbia Pacific University, The University of Delaware and Delaware State University. Dr. Lewis litigated and desegregated an Evanston, Illinois, neighborhood and won a race/ethnic discrimination lawsuit against the Department of Public Instruction (Delaware Department of Education), State of Delaware. He was the first Latino employed by the Delaware Department of Education, and currently teaches Spanish at Middletown High School and is an Adjunct Associate Professor of Spanish and Graduate Education at Delaware State University. He has also been a high school Guidance Counselor and Spanish teacher at several other schools in Delaware and Chicago.

scopecontent.p: The Horacio D. Lewis papers consist of Mr. Lewis's primary source material related to the history of the Panama Canal and to the desegregation of Delaware schools. The desegregation material includes legal documents regarding Lewis as a plaintiff in a suit against the Delaware State Department of Education in 1996. Other material includes clippings, articles, press releases, magazines, books, photocopies, legal documents, and other printed matter for research by Lewis on desegregation and the history of Panama. The papers also include copies of published books and articles written by Lewis on these topics, as well as multicultural education and housing discrimination.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
